image.altText: Downtown Alice

props.synopsis: There are fears a lack of communication around the Alice Springs youth curfew could lead to children being punished by police, after multiple residents told the ABC they were unaware of the declaration.

title.children: 'Children really don't know what this means': Alice Springs curfew communication criticised

image.altText: A huge dome at the top with colourful spinners.

props.synopsis: He's installed his artworks in the home of Beyoncé and Jay-Z and showcased pieces at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Now, Benjamin Shine has unveiled his latest work close to home — in the middle of one of Canberra's newest housing developments.

title.children: His work adorns Beyonce's home and the MET. Now, Benjamin Shine's newest sculpture looks out over a Canberra suburb

image.altText: A shocked-looking woman with dark curly hair holds a laptop in one hand, a phone to her ear in the other

props.synopsis: Let me tell you a sobering and instructive story of how youthful curiosity and low-level larceny can be terribly bad for your financial health. This could be life or death info.

title.children: Was it the husband? Porn? A sobering story of mysterious credit card charges and a dreaded question

props.synopsis: Ruby was told she had a 75 per cent chance of dying if she kept riding bulls. She liked those odds.

title.children: This 13-year-old was one of Australia's best junior bull riders. Then her brain started bleeding

image.altText: A police car with its lights on.

props.synopsis: A Melbourne man has allegedly been caught driving more than 60 kilometres over the speed limit with alcohol in his system while two others have died in separate road incidents so far this Easter long weekend.

title.children: Suspended driver allegedly caught speeding at 171kph while drunk with kids in the car, as Victoria's road toll rises

image.altText: Human eye, seen as if in an hallucinogenic episode.

props.synopsis: There is no cure for HPPD. The condition, triggered by the use of psychedelic drugs, has been described by sufferers as the "trip that never ends".

title.children: Brought on by magic mushrooms or LSD, the lifelong condition that's like being 'stuck in a nightmare'

image.altText: Evan Gershkovich, wearing a plaid shirt, looks up, half his face covered in glass reflection as he stands inside a glass box

props.synopsis: President Joe Biden says the US will impose costs for Russia's "appalling attempts" to use Americans as bargaining chips in a statement to mark the one-year anniversary of the arrest of Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich in Russia, the first of its kind since the Cold War.

title.children: Joe Biden threatens Russia with costs on anniversary of Evan Gershkovich arrest

image.altText: An 1800s illustration of several men dressed as women destroying a fence, as others watch

props.synopsis: Colonial Australia was a brutal place for convicts, but it was more political than previously thought.

title.children: Rethinking our convict past: How the British used convict labour to 'steal a continent'

image.altText: Crucifix

props.synopsis: The victim of prolonged sexual abuse at the hands of a former priest in the 1960s wins a bid to have a settlement agreement set aside, because he couldn't read well enough to understand what he was signing.

title.children: Man who suffered child sexual abuse by former Canberra priest has settlement deed set aside

image.altText: A close-up of a sheep standing in a paddock

props.synopsis: The humble sheep might be considered by some as the perfect embodiment of docility. But they are not mundane mindless mammals — not in the slightest.

title.children: Sheep are 'much cannier' than we give them credit for. These ovine facts may surprise you

image.altText: A photo of a handwritten letter by the two children.

props.synopsis: When eight-year-old Lionel Kennedy and his four-year-old sister Ella Kennedy read the inscription on a memorial at Sydney's Earlwood Oval, they thought something was "not right". Their handwritten letter to council led to change for generations to come.

title.children: 'That's not right': How a handwritten letter led to 'significant' change at a Sydney oval

image.altText: a woman with blonde hair standing on a flooded causeway

props.synopsis: A geoscientist says Cairns can one day expect floods twice as big as the one that inundated hundreds of homes in December.

title.children: Queensland city's flood-prone suburbs in spotlight as geoscientist warns worst yet to come

image.altText: Four wheel driving enthusiasts driving down a muddy track in southern Tasmania

props.synopsis: The Albanese government says it wants more EVs in Australia and wants to provide more "choice" to Australians in the hope they will choose EVs themselves. But how likely is that?

title.children: Australians love big, fuel-hungry utes. What does that mean for the future of EVs — and Australia's climate ambitions?

image.altText: Nicole and Brenda

props.synopsis: The Key Bridge was considered so iconic at the Key Brewery, a nearby namesake, that a big TV beamed a live shot into the bar. Now, the screen displays an empty vista of sky and clouds.

title.children: Once a bustling connector, now a dead end: The communities left in the wake of Baltimore's bridge collapse

image.altText: Lady sitting at a desk on her laptop with a view overlooking a lake

props.synopsis: If you've ever wanted to do your desk job from an exotic location, becoming a digital nomad visa could be for you. Here's what you need to know.

title.children: Dreaming of working remotely from an idyllic location? Here are the countries that offer digital nomad visas

image.altText: Two trucks are stuck in the mud

props.synopsis: One of Australia's most remote communities' food security depends on a remote road that is reaching the point of becoming impassable.

title.children: Still under water and deteriorating, this access road is failing a remote community's food supply

image.altText: An elderly man in a red robe sits bowed in a wheelchair on a rich-looking floor.

props.synopsis: The decision to stay home appears to have taken place at the very last minute, with the pope's chair already in place on the platform outside the Colosseum where he was to preside over a procession.

title.children: Pope skips Good Friday event to preserve health ahead of Easter, Vatican says

image.altText: a young man and woman sit on a log wearing hats in a green forest.

props.synopsis: As tensions rise between China and Taiwan, young people on the island say there are lots more things on their minds than just the thought of war.

title.children: Young Taiwanese speak about the prospect of war with China

image.altText: Calculator and pen on sheets of paper.

props.synopsis: Thousands of not-for-profit organisations fear their financial futures are under threat from a tax change set to kick in next financial year.

title.children: 'It would be crippling': Not-for-profits panic over tax changes

image.altText: A woman works on machinery.

props.synopsis: It's the only program like it in the southern hemisphere — where people who are blind or have low-vision are learning woodturning with unmodified equipment.

title.children: Watch or listen — How Renee Kelly, who was born blind, is learning the craft of woodturning

image.altText: A woman with long blonde hair smiling with teeth in front of a colourful painted outside exterior wall.

props.synopsis:
Whatever your motivation, re-examining your approach buying clothes can be good for your budget and the planet.

We spoke with a stylist, a sustainability advocate and a designer, to get some tips on how to maintain your personal style while being environmentally conscious.

title.children: Why these women are changing their approaches to shopping for clothes

image.altText: A collection of book covers on a green background

props.synopsis: Our favourite new reads include pacy crime fiction from one of Australia's top journalists, a timely reimagining of an American masterpiece and an examination of gender by a ground-breaking philosopher.

title.children: A new book from a feminist icon and a pacey crime thriller are among our fave reads this month

image.altText: Jake looks down slightly with a serious expression, his shirt open over his bare chest and cuts and blood on his face.

props.synopsis: It's the Easter long weekend so that obviously means chocolate and TV. Here's a rundown of the best new shows and movies streaming right now.

title.children: Six new and good shows and movies to watch this Easter long weekend

image.altText: Larissa Crummer runs after the ball as she plays soccer for Australia's Matildas.

props.synopsis: Larissa Crummer announces after a Champions League quarterfinal she will end her football career in Norway and return to Australia to become a plumber and spend more time with her family.

title.children: Crummer the plumber: Matildas star swapping football boots for a wrench and a plunger

image.altText: A woman leans against the wall of a boat shed.

props.synopsis: Nikki Ayers wanted to play for the Australian women's rugby union team, but when a serious knee injury, and multiple surgeries ended that career, she switched to para-rowing, and is now the world's best.

title.children: Para-rower Nikki Ayers embraces gold medal favouritism for Paris Paralympics

image.altText: An elderly man with a button-up shirt with flowers stares at the camera.

props.synopsis: The Organ and Tissue Authority (OTA) has released data for organ donation rates in Australia last year. While there was improvement in the number of transplants, the consent rate by families rose by only one per cent and donor registrations have plummeted.

title.children: Vas has been on the transplant waitlist for 18 months. He is one of 1,800 people in Australia still waiting

image.altText: Eartha Kitt performs at Cafe Carlyle in New York City

props.synopsis: Long before Leonardo DiCaprio lent his voice to environmental causes in Tasmania, legendary American musician and actress Eartha Kitt joined the fray — and it wasn't the only cause close to her heart in Australia.

title.children: Blacklisted for speaking out at home, Eartha Kitt campaigned on Australian causes

image.altText: A portrait photo of Jeffrey Donaldson. He is white, has glasses on, in his 50s and has greying short hair.

props.synopsis: Sir Jeffrey Donaldson, the leader of Northern Ireland's largest unionist party, steps down after being charged over "historical" allegations.

title.children: Northern Ireland's DUP leader resigns after police charges

image.altText: Three police officers stand in a line guarding a street as protesters linger nearby.

props.synopsis: Radio Free Asia says comments by Hong Kong authorities referring to it as a "foreign force" has led to its decision.

title.children: Radio station closes Hong Kong bureau after passing of new security law

image.altText: Richard Marles in a suit with yellow tie shakes hands with a man with grey hair dressed in a suit.

props.synopsis: South Korea's new ambassador to Australia has resigned after less than a month in the job, as he faces a corruption probe at home.

title.children: South Korea's ambassador to Australia resigns after less than a month in the job

image.altText: A screenshot of Tom Dearden's try-saving tackle on Selwyn Cobbo.

props.synopsis: North Queensland half Tom Dearden pulls off a stunning try-saving tackle to deny Selwyn Cobbo early in the second half in Brisbane, but coach Todd Payten says his team's reaction, or lack thereof, was the worst part of a bad night for the Cowboys.

title.children: How Tom Dearden's miracle try-saver turned into 'the most disappointing part' of the Cowboys' thrashing by Brisbane

image.altText: Young woman sits on a lawn smiling with a small dog on her kap.

props.synopsis: Dogs like Spryte the Tenterfield terrier are finding their way from animal shelters to jobs as assistance animals, providing another option for people who may not be able to fork out for designer breeds.

title.children: Rescue dogs in demand to become medical assistance animals as patients seek more affordable breeds

image.altText: A graphic showing magpies in the shape of a question mark.

props.synopsis: For more than 120 years, a question involving magpies has endlessly ruffled feathers — why is the bird on South Australia's state flag called a piping shrike? Trying to come up with an answer can feel like a wild goose chase, but ornithologists insist there's a simple solution.

title.children: Magpies, magpie-larks and the striking mystery of the piping shrike
